The [Allied](/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II "Allies of World War II")
**occupation of Japan** at the end of [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World
War II") was led by General [Douglas MacArthur](/wiki/Douglas_MacArthur
"Douglas MacArthur"), the [Supreme Commander of the Allied
Powers](/wiki/Supreme_Commander_of_the_Allied_Powers "Supreme Commander of the
Allied Powers"), with [support](/wiki/British_Commonwealth_Occupation_Force
"British Commonwealth Occupation Force") from the [British
Commonwealth](/wiki/British_Commonwealth "British Commonwealth"). Unlike in
the [occupation of Germany](/wiki/Allied-occupied_Germany "Allied-occupied
Germany"), the [Soviet Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union") was allowed
little to no influence over [Japan](/wiki/Japan "Japan"). This foreign
presence marks the only time in Japan's history that it has been occupied by a
foreign power.[1] The country became a [parliamentary
democracy](/wiki/Parliamentary_system "Parliamentary system") that recalled
"[New Deal](/wiki/New_Deal "New Deal")" priorities of the 1930s by
[Roosevelt](/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt "Franklin D. Roosevelt").[2] The
occupation, [codenamed](/wiki/Codename "Codename") **Operation _Blacklist_**
,[3] was ended by the [San Francisco Peace
Treaty](/wiki/San_Francisco_Peace_Treaty "San Francisco Peace Treaty"), signed
on September 8, 1951, and [effective from](/wiki/Coming_into_force "Coming
into force") April 28, 1952, after which Japan's sovereignty – with the
[exception](/wiki/United_States_Civil_Administration_of_the_Ryukyu_Islands
"United States Civil Administration of the Ryukyu Islands"), until 1972, of
the [Ryukyu Islands](/wiki/Ryukyu_Islands "Ryukyu Islands") – was fully
restored.

According to [John Dower](/wiki/John_W._Dower "John W. Dower"), in his book
_Cultures of War: Pearl Harbor/Hiroshima/9-11/Iraq_ , the factors behind the
success of the occupation were:

> Discipline, moral legitimacy, well-defined and well-articulated objectives,
> a clear chain of command, tolerance and flexibility in policy formulation
> and implementation, confidence in the ability of the state to act
> constructively, the ability to operate abroad free of partisan politics back
> home, and the existence of a stable, resilient, sophisticated civil society
> on the receiving end of occupation policies – these political and civic
> virtues helped make it possible to move decisively during the brief window
> of a few years when defeated Japan itself was in flux and most receptive to
> radical change.[4]

## Japanese
surrender[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Occupation_of_Japan&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Japanese surrender")]

Main article: [Surrender of Japan](/wiki/Surrender_of_Japan "Surrender of
Japan")

### Initial
phase[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Occupation_of_Japan&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Initial phase")]

Japan surrendered to the Allies on August 14, 1945, when the Japanese
government notified the Allies that it had accepted the [Potsdam
Declaration](/wiki/Potsdam_Declaration "Potsdam Declaration"). On the
following day, Emperor [Hirohito](/wiki/Hirohito "Hirohito") announced Japan's
unconditional surrender on the radio (the _[Gyokuon-
hōsō](/wiki/Gyokuon-h%C5%8Ds%C5%8D "Gyokuon-hōsō")_). The announcement was the
emperor's first ever planned radio broadcast and the first time most citizens
of Japan ever heard their sovereign's voice.[5] This date is known as Victory
over Japan, or [V-J Day](/wiki/Victory_over_Japan_Day "Victory over Japan
Day"), and marked the end of [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II")
and the beginning of a long road to recovery for a shattered Japan. Japanese
officials left for [Manila](/wiki/Manila "Manila"), Philippines on August 19
to meet MacArthur and to be briefed on his plans for the occupation. On August
28, 1945, 150 US personnel flew to [Atsugi](/wiki/Atsugi "Atsugi"), [Kanagawa
Prefecture](/wiki/Kanagawa_Prefecture "Kanagawa Prefecture"). They were
followed by [USS _Missouri_](/wiki/USS_Missouri_\(BB-63\) "USS Missouri
\(BB-63\)"),[6] whose accompanying vessels landed the [4th Marine
Division](/wiki/US_4th_Marine_Division "US 4th Marine Division") on the
southern coast of Kanagawa. Other Allied personnel followed.

MacArthur arrived in [Tokyo](/wiki/Tokyo "Tokyo") on August 30, and
immediately decreed several laws. No Allied personnel were to assault Japanese
people. No Allied personnel were to eat the scarce Japanese food. Flying the
_[Hinomaru](/wiki/Hinomaru "Hinomaru")_ or "Rising Sun" flag was initially
severely restricted (although individuals and prefectural offices could apply
for permission to fly it). This restriction was partially lifted in 1948 and
completely lifted the following year.[7]

[](/wiki/File:Instrument_of_surrender_Japan2.jpg "Enlarge")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Surrender_of_Japan_-
_USS_Missouri.jpg/220px-Surrender_of_Japan_-
_USS_Missouri.jpg)](/wiki/File:Surrender_of_Japan_-_USS_Missouri.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Surrender_of_Japan_-_USS_Missouri.jpg "Enlarge")

Representatives of the Empire of Japan stand aboard the [USS
_Missouri_](/wiki/USS_Missouri_\(BB-63\) "USS Missouri \(BB-63\)") prior to
signing of the Instrument of Surrender.

On September 2, 1945, Japan formally surrendered with the signing of the
[Japanese Instrument of Surrender](/wiki/Japanese_Instrument_of_Surrender
"Japanese Instrument of Surrender"). On September 6, US President Truman
approved a document titled "[US Initial Post-Surrender Policy for
Japan](/wiki/US_Initial_Post-Surrender_Policy_for_Japan "US Initial Post-
Surrender Policy for Japan")".[8] The document set two main objectives for the
occupation: (1) eliminating Japan's war potential and (2) turning Japan into a
[democratic-style](/wiki/Democracy "Democracy") nation with pro-United Nations
orientation. Allied (primarily American) forces were set up to supervise the
country, and "for eighty months following its surrender in 1945, Japan was at
the mercy of an army of occupation, its people subject to foreign military
control."[9] At the head of the Occupation administration was General
MacArthur, who was technically supposed to defer to an advisory council set up
by the Allied powers, but in practice did not and did everything himself. As a
result, this period was one of significant American influence, described near
the end of the occupation in 1951 that "for six years the United States has
had a free hand to experiment with Japan than any other country in Asia, or
indeed in the entire world."[10] Looking back to his work among the Japanese,
MacArthur said, "Measured by the standards of modern civilization, they would
be like a boy of twelve" compared to the maturity of the US and Germany, and
had a good chance of putting away their troubled past.[11]

### SCAP[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Occupation_of_Japan&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: SCAP")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/The_first_proposals_for_the_division_of_Japan_-
_WW2.png/220px-The_first_proposals_for_the_division_of_Japan_-
_WW2.png)](/wiki/File:The_first_proposals_for_the_division_of_Japan_-_WW2.png)

[](/wiki/File:The_first_proposals_for_the_division_of_Japan_-_WW2.png
"Enlarge")

The first proposals for the division of Japan

On V-J Day, US President [Harry Truman](/wiki/Harry_Truman "Harry Truman")
appointed General [Douglas MacArthur](/wiki/Douglas_MacArthur "Douglas
MacArthur") as [Supreme Commander for the Allied
Powers](/wiki/Supreme_Commander_for_the_Allied_Powers "Supreme Commander for
the Allied Powers") (SCAP), to supervise the occupation of Japan. During the
war, the Allied Powers had planned to divide Japan amongst themselves for the
purposes of occupation, as was done for the [occupation of
Germany](/wiki/Occupation_of_Germany "Occupation of Germany"). Under the final
plan, however, SCAP was given direct control over the main islands of Japan
([Honshu](/wiki/Honshu "Honshu"), [Hokkaido](/wiki/Hokkaido "Hokkaido"),
[Shikoku](/wiki/Shikoku "Shikoku"), and [Kyushu](/wiki/Kyushu "Kyushu")) and
the immediately surrounding islands, while outlying possessions were divided
between the Allied Powers as follows:

  * [Soviet Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union"): [North Korea](/wiki/North_Korea "North Korea") (not a full occupation), [South Sakhalin](/wiki/South_Sakhalin "South Sakhalin"), and the [Kuril Islands](/wiki/Kuril_Islands "Kuril Islands")
  * [United States](/wiki/United_States "United States"): [South Korea](/wiki/South_Korea "South Korea") (not a full occupation), [Okinawa](/wiki/Okinawa "Okinawa"), the [Amami Islands](/wiki/Amami_Islands "Amami Islands"), the [Ogasawara Islands](/wiki/Ogasawara_Islands "Ogasawara Islands") and Japanese possessions in [Micronesia](/wiki/Micronesia "Micronesia")
  * [China](/wiki/Republic_of_China_\(1912%E2%80%9349\) "Republic of China \(1912–49\)"): [Taiwan](/wiki/Taiwan_after_World_War_II "Taiwan after World War II") and [Penghu](/wiki/Penghu "Penghu")

It is unclear why the occupation plan was changed. Common theories include the
increased power of the United States following development of the [atomic
bomb](/wiki/Atomic_bomb "Atomic bomb"), Truman's greater distrust of the
Soviet Union when compared with Roosevelt, and an increased desire to restrict
Soviet influence in [East Asia](/wiki/East_Asia "East Asia") after the [Yalta
Conference](/wiki/Yalta_Conference "Yalta Conference").

The Soviet Union had some intentions of occupying Hokkaidō.[12] Had this
occurred, there might have eventually been a [communist
state](/wiki/Communist_state "Communist state") in the Soviet zone of
occupation. However, unlike the [Soviet occupations](/wiki/Soviet_occupations
"Soviet occupations") of [East Germany](/wiki/East_Germany "East Germany") and
[North Korea](/wiki/North_Korea "North Korea"), these plans were frustrated by
Truman's opposition.[12]

MacArthur's first priority was to set up a food distribution network;
following the collapse of the ruling government and the wholesale destruction
of most major cities, virtually everyone was starving. Even with these
measures, millions of people were still on the brink of starvation for several
years after the surrender.[13] As expressed by Kawai Kazuo, "Democracy cannot
be taught to a starving people".[14] The US government encouraged democratic
reform in Japan, and while it sent billions of dollars in food aid, this was
dwarfed by the occupation costs it imposed on the struggling Japanese
administration.[15][16]

![File:Gaetano Faillace - Occupied Tokyo -
film.webm](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Gaetano_Faillace_-
_Occupied_Tokyo_-_film.webm/220px-seek%3D1-Gaetano_Faillace_-_Occupied_Tokyo_-
_film.webm.jpg)[Play
media](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/45/Gaetano_Faillace_-
_Occupied_Tokyo_-_film.webm "Play media")

[](/wiki/File:Gaetano_Faillace_-_Occupied_Tokyo_-_film.webm "Enlarge")

Half destroyed Tokyo as filmed by [Gaetano Faillace](/wiki/Gaetano_Faillace
"Gaetano Faillace")

Initially, the US government provided emergency food relief through Government
and Relief in Occupied Areas ([GARIOA](/wiki/GARIOA "GARIOA")) funds. In
fiscal year 1946, this aid amounted to US$92 million in loans. From April
1946, in the guise of [Licensed Agencies for Relief in
Asia](/wiki/Licensed_Agencies_for_Relief_in_Asia "Licensed Agencies for Relief
in Asia"), private relief organizations were also permitted to provide relief.
Once the food network was in place MacArthur set out to win the support of
Hirohito. The two men met for the first time on September 27; the photograph
of the two together is one of the most famous in Japanese history. Some were
shocked that MacArthur wore his standard duty uniform with no tie instead of
his dress uniform when meeting the emperor. With the sanction of Japan's
reigning monarch, MacArthur had the ammunition he needed to begin the real
work of the occupation. While other Allied political and military leaders
pushed for Hirohito to be tried as a [war criminal](/wiki/War_crimes "War
crimes"), MacArthur resisted such calls, arguing that any such prosecution
would be overwhelmingly unpopular with the Japanese people. He also rejected
the claims of members of the imperial family such as [Prince
Mikasa](/wiki/Prince_Mikasa "Prince Mikasa") and [Prince
Higashikuni](/wiki/Prince_Higashikuni "Prince Higashikuni") and demands of
intellectuals like [Tatsuji Miyoshi](/wiki/Tatsuji_Miyoshi "Tatsuji Miyoshi"),
who sought the emperor's abdication.[17]

By the end of 1945, more than 350,000 US personnel were stationed throughout
Japan. By the beginning of 1946, replacement troops began to arrive in the
country in large numbers and were assigned to MacArthur's [Eighth
Army](/wiki/Eighth_United_States_Army "Eighth United States Army"),
headquartered in Tokyo's [Dai-Ichi](/wiki/DN_Tower_21 "DN Tower 21") building.
Of the main Japanese islands, [Kyūshū](/wiki/Ky%C5%ABsh%C5%AB "Kyūshū") was
occupied by the [24th Infantry Division](/wiki/U.S._24th_Infantry_Division
"U.S. 24th Infantry Division"), with some responsibility for
[Shikoku](/wiki/Shikoku "Shikoku"). [Honshu](/wiki/Honshu "Honshu") was
occupied by the [First Cavalry
Division](/wiki/1st_Cavalry_Division_\(United_States\) "1st Cavalry Division
\(United States\)"). [Hokkaido](/wiki/Hokkaido "Hokkaido") was occupied by the
[11th Airborne Division](/wiki/U.S._11th_Airborne_Division "U.S. 11th Airborne
Division").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/5th_Gurkha_Rifles%2C_Japan_1946.jpg/220px-5th_Gurkha_Rifles%2C_Japan_1946.jpg)](/wiki/File:5th_Gurkha_Rifles,_Japan_1946.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:5th_Gurkha_Rifles,_Japan_1946.jpg "Enlarge")

May 1946. The 2nd Battalion [5th Royal Gurkha
Rifles](/wiki/5th_Royal_Gurkha_Rifles "5th Royal Gurkha Rifles") march through
[Kure, Hiroshima](/wiki/Kure,_Hiroshima "Kure, Hiroshima") soon after their
arrival in Japan.

By June 1950, all these army units had suffered extensive troop reductions and
their combat effectiveness was seriously weakened. When North Korea invaded
South Korea in the [Korean War](/wiki/Korean_War "Korean War"), elements of
the 24th Division were flown into South Korea to try to fight the invasion
force there, but the inexperienced occupation troops, while acquitting
themselves well when suddenly thrown into combat almost overnight, suffered
heavy casualties and were forced into retreat until other Japan occupation
troops could be sent to assist.

### Organs running in parallel to
SCAP[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Occupation_of_Japan&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Organs running in parallel to SCAP")]

The official [British Commonwealth Occupation
Force](/wiki/British_Commonwealth_Occupation_Force "British Commonwealth
Occupation Force") (BCOF), composed of
[Australian](/wiki/Australian_Defence_Force "Australian Defence Force"),
[British](/wiki/British_Armed_Forces "British Armed Forces"),
[Indian](/wiki/British_Indian_Army "British Indian Army") and [New
Zealand](/wiki/New_Zealand_Defence_Force "New Zealand Defence Force")
personnel, was deployed on February 21, 1946. While US forces were responsible
for the overall occupation, BCOF was responsible for supervising
demilitarization and the disposal of Japan's war industries.[18] BCOF was also
responsible for occupation of several western prefectures and had its
headquarters at [Kure](/wiki/Kure,_Hiroshima "Kure, Hiroshima"). At its peak,
the force numbered about 40,000 personnel. During 1947, BCOF began to decrease
its activities in Japan, and officially wound up in 1951.

The [Far Eastern Commission](/wiki/Far_Eastern_Commission "Far Eastern
Commission") and Allied Council for Japan were also established to supervise
the occupation of Japan.[19] The establishment of a multilateral Allied
council for Japan was proposed by the Soviet government as early as September
1945, and was supported partially by the British, French and Chinese
governments.[20]

###
Disarmament[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Occupation_of_Japan&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Disarmament")]

Japan's postwar [constitution](/wiki/Constitution_of_Japan "Constitution of
Japan"), adopted under Allied supervision, included a "Peace Clause", [Article
9](/wiki/Article_9_of_the_Japanese_Constitution "Article 9 of the Japanese
Constitution"), which renounced war and banned Japan from maintaining any
armed forces. This clause was not imposed by the Allies: rather, it was the
work of the Japanese government itself, and according to most sources, was the
work of Prime Minister [Kijūrō Shidehara](/wiki/Kij%C5%ABr%C5%8D_Shidehara
"Kijūrō Shidehara").[21][22] The clause was intended to prevent the country
from ever becoming an aggressive military power again. However, the United
States was soon pressuring Japan to rebuild its army as a bulwark against
[communism](/wiki/Communism "Communism") in Asia after the [Chinese Civil
War](/wiki/Chinese_Civil_War "Chinese Civil War") and the [Korean
War](/wiki/Korean_War "Korean War"). During the Korean War, US forces largely
withdrew from Japan to redeploy to South Korea, leaving the country almost
totally defenseless. As a result, a new [National Police
Reserve](/wiki/National_Police_Reserve "National Police Reserve") armed with
military-grade weaponry was created. In 1954, the [Japan Self-Defense
Forces](/wiki/Japan_Self-Defense_Forces "Japan Self-Defense Forces") were
founded as a full-scale military in all but name. To avoid breaking the
constitutional prohibition on military force, they were officially founded as
an extension to the police force. Traditionally, Japan's military spending has
been restricted to about 1% of its [gross national
product](/wiki/Gross_national_product "Gross national product"), though this
is by popular practice, not law, and has [fluctuated up and
down](/wiki/Defense_budget_of_Japan "Defense budget of Japan") from this
figure. [Prime Ministers](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Japan "Prime Minister of
Japan") [Junichiro Koizumi](/wiki/Junichiro_Koizumi "Junichiro Koizumi") and
[Shinzo Abe](/wiki/Shinzo_Abe "Shinzo Abe"), among others, have tried to
repeal or amend the clause. The JSDF slowly grew to considerable strength, and
Japan now has the [eighth largest military
budget](/wiki/List_of_countries_by_military_expenditure "List of countries by
military expenditure") in the world.[23]

###
Liberalization[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Occupation_of_Japan&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Liberalization")]

All the major sectors of the Japanese society, government, and economy were
liberalized in the first few years and won strong support from
[liberals](/wiki/Liberalism "Liberalism") in Japan.[24] Historians emphasize
the similarity to the American [New Deal](/wiki/New_Deal "New Deal") programs
of the 1930s.[25] Moore and Robinson note that, "New Deal liberalism seemed
natural, even to conservative Republicans such as MacArthur and
[Whitney](/wiki/Courtney_Whitney "Courtney Whitney")."[26] The issuing of the
[Removal of Restrictions on Political, Civil, and Religious
Liberties](/wiki/Removal_of_Restrictions_on_Political,_Civil,_and_Religious_Liberties
"Removal of Restrictions on Political, Civil, and Religious Liberties")
directive by SCAP on October 4, 1945, led to the abolishment of the [Peace
Preservation Law](/wiki/Peace_Preservation_Law "Peace Preservation Law") and
the release of all political prisoners.[27][28]

### Emphasis on stability and economic
growth[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Occupation_of_Japan&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Emphasis on stability and economic growth")]

From late 1947, US priorities shifted to internal political stability and
economic growth. Economic deconcentration, for example, was left uncompleted
as GHQ responded to new imperatives. American authorities encouraged business
practices and industrial policies that have since become sources of contention
between Japan and its major trade partners, notably the United States.[29]
During the occupation, GHQ/SCAP mostly abolished many of the financial
coalitions known as the [Zaibatsu](/wiki/Zaibatsu "Zaibatsu"), which had
previously monopolized industry.[30] Along with the later American change of
heart, and due in part to the need for an economically stronger Japan in the
face of a perceived Soviet threat, these economic reforms were also hampered
by the wealthy and influential Japanese who stood to lose a great deal. As
such, there were those who consequently resisted any attempts at reform,
claiming that the zaibatsu were required for Japan to compete internationally,
and looser industrial groupings known as [keiretsu](/wiki/Keiretsu "Keiretsu")
evolved. A major [land reform](/wiki/Land_reform "Land reform") was also
conducted, led by [Wolf Ladejinsky](/wiki/Wolf_Ladejinsky "Wolf Ladejinsky")
of General [Douglas MacArthur](/wiki/Douglas_MacArthur "Douglas MacArthur")'s
[SCAP](/wiki/Supreme_Commander_of_the_Allied_Powers "Supreme Commander of the
Allied Powers") staff. However, Ladejinsky has stated that the real architect
of reform was [Hiro Wada](/w/index.php?title=Hiro_Wada&action=edit&redlink=1
"Hiro Wada \(page does not exist\)"), former Japanese [Minister of
Agriculture](/wiki/Minister_of_Agriculture "Minister of Agriculture").[31]
Between 1947 and 1949, approximately 5,800,000 acres (23,000 km2) of land
(approximately 38% of Japan's cultivated land) were purchased from the
[landlords](/wiki/Landlord "Landlord") under the government's reform program
and resold at extremely low prices (after inflation) to the farmers who worked
them. By 1950, three million peasants had acquired land, dismantling a power
structure that the landlords had long dominated.[32]

###
Democratization[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Occupation_of_Japan&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Democratization")]

In 1946, the Diet ratified a new [Constitution of
Japan](/wiki/Constitution_of_Japan "Constitution of Japan") that followed
closely a 'model copy' prepared by the GHQ/SCAP,[33] and was promulgated as an
amendment to the old [Prussian](/wiki/Prussia "Prussia")-style [Meiji
Constitution](/wiki/Meiji_Constitution "Meiji Constitution"). The new
constitution drafted by Americans allowed access and control over the Japanese
military through MacArthur and the Allied occupation on Japan.[34] "The
political project drew much of its inspiration from the [U.S. Bill of
Rights](/wiki/US_Bill_of_Rights "US Bill of Rights"), [New
Deal](/wiki/New_Deal "New Deal") social legislation, the [liberal
constitutions](/wiki/Liberal_constitution "Liberal constitution") of several
European states and even the Soviet Union.... (It) transferred sovereignty
from the Emperor to the people in an attempt to depoliticize the Throne and
reduce it to the status of a state symbol. Included in the revised charter was
the famous 'no war', 'no arms' Article Nine, which outlawed belligerency as an
instrument of state policy and the maintenance of a standing army. The 1947
Constitution also enfranchised women, guaranteed fundamental human rights,
strengthened the powers of Parliament and the Cabinet, and decentralized the
police and local government."[35] One example of MacArthur's push towards
democratization implemented the land reform and redistribution of ownership
within the agricultural system.[36] The land reform was established in order
to improve not only the economy but the welfare of farmers as well.[37]
MacArthur's land reform policy redistribution resulted in only 10% of the land
being worked by non-owners.[36] On December 15, 1945, the [Shinto
Directive](/wiki/Shinto_Directive "Shinto Directive") was issued abolishing
[Shinto](/wiki/Shinto "Shinto") as a [state religion](/wiki/State_religion
"State religion") and prohibiting some of its teachings and rites that were
deemed to be militaristic or ultra-nationalistic. On April 10, 1946, an
election with 78.52% voter turnout among men and 66.97% among women[38] gave
Japan its first modern prime minister, [Shigeru Yoshida](/wiki/Shigeru_Yoshida
"Shigeru Yoshida").

### Trade Union
Act[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Occupation_of_Japan&action=edit&section=10 "Edit
section: Trade Union Act")]

In 1945 the Diet passed Japan's first ever trade union law protecting the
rights of workers to form or join a union, to organize, and take industrial
action. There had been pre-war attempts to do so, but none that were
successfully passed until the Allied occupation.[39] A new [Trade Union
Law](/wiki/Trade_Union_Act_of_1949 "Trade Union Act of 1949") was passed on
June 1, 1949, which remains in place to the present day. According to Article
1 of the Act, the purpose of the act is to "elevate the status of workers by
promoting their being on equal standing with the employer".[40]

### Labor Standards
Act[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Occupation_of_Japan&action=edit&section=11 "Edit
section: Labor Standards Act")]

The [Labor Standards Act](/wiki/Labor_Standards_Act_of_1947 "Labor Standards
Act of 1947") was enacted on April 7, 1947, to govern working conditions in
Japan. According to Article 1 of the Act, its goal is to ensure that "Working
conditions shall be those which should meet the needs of workers who live
lives worthy of human beings."[41] Support stemming from the Allied occupation
has introduced better working conditions and pay for numerous employees in
Japanese business.[36] This allowed for more sanitary and hygienic working
environments along with welfare and government assistance for health
insurance, pensions plans and work involving other trained specialists.[36]
While it was created while Japan was under occupation, the origins of the Act
have nothing to do with the occupation forces. It appears to have been the
brainchild of Kosaku Teramoto, a former member of the [Thought
Police](/wiki/Tokubetsu_K%C5%8Dt%C5%8D_Keisatsu "Tokubetsu Kōtō Keisatsu"),
who had become the head of the Labor Standards section of the Welfare
Ministry.[42]

### Education
reform[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Occupation_of_Japan&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Education reform")]

See also: [Educational reform in occupied
Japan](/wiki/Educational_reform_in_occupied_Japan "Educational reform in
occupied Japan")

Before and during the war, [Japanese
education](/wiki/History_of_education_in_Japan "History of education in
Japan") was based on the German system, with
"[Gymnasien](/wiki/Gymnasium_\(Germany\) "Gymnasium \(Germany\)")" (selective
grammar schools) and universities to train students after primary school.
During the occupation, Japan's secondary education system was changed to
incorporate three-year junior high schools and senior high schools similar to
those in the US: junior high school became compulsory but senior high school
remained optional. The [Imperial Rescript on
Education](/wiki/Imperial_Rescript_on_Education "Imperial Rescript on
Education") was repealed, and the Imperial University system reorganized. The
longstanding issue of [Japanese script reform](/wiki/Japanese_script_reform
"Japanese script reform"), which had been planned for decades but continuously
opposed by more conservative elements, was also resolved during this time. The
Japanese written system was drastically reorganized with the [Tōyō
kanji](/wiki/Japanese_script_reform#Tōyō_kanji "Japanese script reform")-list
in 1946, predecessor of today's [Jōyō kanji](/wiki/J%C5%8Dy%C5%8D_kanji "Jōyō
kanji"), and orthography was greatly altered to reflect spoken usage.

### Women's
rights[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Occupation_of_Japan&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Women's rights")]

Prior to [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"), women in Japan
were denied the [right to vote](/wiki/Right_to_vote "Right to vote") and other
[legal rights](/wiki/Legal_rights "Legal rights"). With the defeat of the
traditionalist government, the occupation authorities, on the order of general
[Douglas MacArthur](/wiki/Douglas_MacArthur "Douglas MacArthur"), began
drafting a new [constitution for
Japan](/wiki/Constitution_of_Japan#Drafting_process "Constitution of Japan")
in February 1946. A subcommittee including two women, [Beate Sirota
Gordon](/wiki/Beate_Sirota_Gordon "Beate Sirota Gordon")[43] and economist
[Eleanor Hadley](/wiki/Eleanor_Hadley "Eleanor Hadley"), was enlisted and
assigned to writing the section of the constitution devoted to [civil
rights](/wiki/Civil_rights "Civil rights") and [women's rights in
Japan](/wiki/Women%27s_rights#Japan "Women's rights"). They played an integral
role, drafting the language regarding legal equality between men and women in
Japan,[44] including Articles 14 and 24 on Equal Rights and Women's Civil
Rights. Article 14 states, in part: "All of the people are equal under the law
and there shall be no discrimination in political, economic or social
relations because of race, creed, sex, social status or family origin".
Article 24 includes:

> Marriage shall be based only on the mutual consent of both sexes and it
> shall be maintained through mutual cooperation with the equal rights of
> husband and wife as a basis. 2) With regard to choice of spouse, property
> rights, inheritance, choice of domicile, divorce and other matters
> pertaining to marriage and the family, laws shall be enacted from the
> standpoint of individual dignity and the essential equality of the sexes.

These additions to the constitution were vital to women's rights in Japan.
"Japanese women were historically treated like
[chattel](/wiki/Personal_property "Personal property"); they were property to
be bought and sold on a whim," Gordon said in 1999.[45]

### Release of political
prisoners[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Occupation_of_Japan&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Release of political prisoners")]

Release_of_Communist.JPG)](/wiki/File:Release_of_Communist.JPG)

On October 4, 1945, the GHQ issued the [Removal of Restrictions on Political,

### War
criminals[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Occupation_of_Japan&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: War criminals")]

While these other reforms were taking place, various military tribunals, most
notably the [International Military Tribunal for the Far
East](/wiki/International_Military_Tribunal_for_the_Far_East "International
Military Tribunal for the Far East") in [Ichigaya](/wiki/Ichigaya "Ichigaya"),
were trying Japan's [war criminals](/wiki/Japanese_war_crimes "Japanese war
crimes") and sentencing many to death and imprisonment. However, many suspects
such as [Masanobu Tsuji](/wiki/Masanobu_Tsuji "Masanobu Tsuji"), [Nobusuke
Kishi](/wiki/Nobusuke_Kishi "Nobusuke Kishi"), [Yoshio
Kodama](/wiki/Yoshio_Kodama "Yoshio Kodama") and [Ryōichi
Sasakawa](/wiki/Ry%C5%8Dichi_Sasakawa "Ryōichi Sasakawa") were never judged,
while the Emperor [Hirohito](/wiki/Hirohito "Hirohito"), all members of the
imperial family implicated in the war such as [Prince
Chichibu](/wiki/Yasuhito,_Prince_Chichibu "Yasuhito, Prince Chichibu"),
[Prince Yasuhiko Asaka](/wiki/Prince_Yasuhiko_Asaka "Prince Yasuhiko Asaka"),
[Prince Fushimi Hiroyasu](/wiki/Prince_Fushimi_Hiroyasu "Prince Fushimi
Hiroyasu"), [Prince Naruhiko Higashikuni](/wiki/Prince_Naruhiko_Higashikuni
"Prince Naruhiko Higashikuni") and [Prince Tsuneyoshi
Takeda](/wiki/Prince_Tsuneyoshi_Takeda "Prince Tsuneyoshi Takeda"), and all
members of [Unit 731](/wiki/Unit_731 "Unit 731")—including its director Dr.
[Shirō Ishii](/wiki/Shir%C5%8D_Ishii "Shirō Ishii")—were granted immunity from
criminal prosecution by General MacArthur.

Before the war crimes trials actually convened, the SCAP, the
[IPS](/wiki/International_Peace_and_Security "International Peace and
Security") and [Shōwa](/wiki/Sh%C5%8Dwa_period "Shōwa period") officials
worked behind the scenes not only to prevent the imperial family from being
indicted, but also to slant the testimony of the defendants to ensure that no
one implicated the Emperor. High officials in court circles and the Shōwa
government collaborated with Allied GHQ in compiling lists of prospective war
criminals, while the individuals arrested as _Class A_ suspects and
incarcerated in [Sugamo](/wiki/Sugamo "Sugamo") prison solemnly vowed to
protect their sovereign against any possible taint of war responsibility.[47]
Thus, months before the [Tokyo tribunal](/wiki/Tokyo_tribunal "Tokyo
tribunal") commenced, MacArthur's highest subordinates were working to
attribute ultimate responsibility for [Pearl
Harbor](/wiki/Attack_on_Pearl_Harbor "Attack on Pearl Harbor") to [Hideki
Tojo](/wiki/Hideki_Tojo "Hideki Tojo")"[48] by allowing "the major criminal
suspects to coordinate their stories so that the Emperor would be spared from
indictment."[49] and "with the full support of MacArthur's headquarters, the
prosecution functioned, in effect, as a defense team for the emperor.[50]

For historian [John W. Dower](/wiki/John_W._Dower "John W. Dower"),

> Even Japanese peace activists who endorse the ideals of the Nuremberg and
> Tokyo charters, and who have labored to document and publicize Japanese
> atrocities, cannot defend the American decision to exonerate the emperor of
> war responsibility and then, in the chill of [Cold war](/wiki/Cold_war "Cold
> war"), release and soon afterwards openly embrace accused right-wing war
> criminals like the later prime minister [Kishi
> Nobusuke](/wiki/Kishi_Nobusuke "Kishi Nobusuke").[51]
>
> In retrospect, apart from the military officer corps, the purge of alleged
> militarists and ultranationalists that was conducted under the Occupation
> had relatively small impact on the long-term composition of men of influence
> in the public and private sectors. The purge initially brought new blood
> into the political parties, but this was offset by the return of huge
> numbers of formally purged conservative politicians to national as well as
> local politics in the early 1950s. In the bureaucracy, the purge was
> negligible from the outset.... In the economic sector, the purge similarly
> was only mildly disruptive, affecting less than sixteen hundred individuals
> spread among some four hundred companies. Everywhere one looks, the
> corridors of power in postwar Japan are crowded with men whose talents had
> already been recognized during the war years, and who found the same talents
> highly prized in the "new" Japan.[52]

### Rape[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Occupation_of_Japan&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Rape")]

Main article: [Rape during the occupation of
Japan](/wiki/Rape_during_the_occupation_of_Japan "Rape during the occupation
of Japan")

According to various accounts, U.S. troops committed thousands of rapes among
the population of the [Ryukyu Islands](/wiki/Ryukyu_Islands "Ryukyu Islands")
during the [Okinawa Campaign](/wiki/Okinawa_Campaign "Okinawa Campaign") and
the beginning of the American occupation in 1945.[53][54]

Many Japanese civilians in the Japanese mainland feared that the Allied
occupation troops were likely to rape Japanese women. The Japanese authorities
set up a large system of prostitution facilities ([Recreation and Amusement
Association](/wiki/Recreation_and_Amusement_Association "Recreation and
Amusement Association"), or the RAA) in order to protect the population.
According to [John W. Dower](/wiki/John_W._Dower "John W. Dower"), precisely
as the Japanese government had hoped when it created the prostitution
facilities, while the RAA was in place "the incidence of rape remained
relatively low given the huge size of the occupation force".[55]:130 However,
there was a resulting large rise in venereal disease among the soldiers, which
led MacArthur to close down the prostitution in early 1946.[56] The incidence
of rape increased after the closure of the brothels, possibly eight-fold;
Dower states that "According to one calculation the number of rapes and
assaults on Japanese women amounted to around 40 _daily_ while the RAA was in
operation, and then rose to an average of 330 a day after it was terminated in
early 1946."[57] Michael S. Molasky states that while rape and other violent
crime were widespread in naval ports like [Yokosuka](/wiki/Yokosuka
"Yokosuka") and [Yokohama](/wiki/Yokohama "Yokohama") during the first few
weeks of occupation, according to Japanese police reports and journalistic
studies, the number of incidents declined shortly after and they were not
common on mainland Japan throughout the rest of occupation.[58] Two weeks into
the occupation, the Occupation administration began censoring all media. This
included any mention of rape or other sensitive social issues.[59][60]

According to Dower, "more than a few incidents" of assault and rape were never
reported to the police.[61] According to Toshiyuki Tanaka, 76 cases of rape or
rape-murder were reported on Okinawa during the first five years of
occupation, but according to Tanaka this is "but the tip of the iceberg" as
most of the rapes went unreported.[62]

###
Censorship[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Occupation_of_Japan&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: Censorship")]

See also: [Censorship in Japan § Occupation of
Japan](/wiki/Censorship_in_Japan#Occupation_of_Japan "Censorship in Japan"),
[Rape during the occupation of Japan § Allied censorship of Japanese
media](/wiki/Rape_during_the_occupation_of_Japan#Allied_censorship_of_Japanese_media
"Rape during the occupation of Japan"), and [Civil Censorship
Detachment](/wiki/Civil_Censorship_Detachment "Civil Censorship Detachment")

After the [surrender of Japan](/wiki/Surrender_of_Japan "Surrender of Japan")
in 1945, the [Supreme Commander of the Allied
Powers](/wiki/Supreme_Commander_of_the_Allied_Powers "Supreme Commander of the
Allied Powers") abolished all forms of censorship and controls on [Freedom of
Speech](/wiki/Freedom_of_Speech "Freedom of Speech"), which was also
integrated into Article 21 of the 1947 [Constitution of
Japan](/wiki/Constitution_of_Japan "Constitution of Japan"). However, press
censorship remained a reality in the post-war era, especially in matters of
pornography, and in political matters deemed subversive by the American
government during the occupation of Japan.

The Allied occupation forces suppressed news of criminal activities such as
rape; on September 10, 1945, SCAP "issued press and pre-censorship codes
outlawing the publication of all reports and statistics 'inimical to the
objectives of the Occupation'."[63]

According to David M. Rosenfeld:

> Not only did Occupation censorship forbid criticism of the United States or
> other Allied nations, but the mention of censorship itself was forbidden.
> This means, as [Donald Keene](/wiki/Donald_Keene "Donald Keene") observes,
> that for some producers of texts "the Occupation censorship was even more
> exasperating than Japanese military censorship had been because it insisted
> that all traces of censorship be concealed. This meant that articles had to
> be rewritten in full, rather than merely submitting XXs for the offending
> phrases."
>
> — Donald Keene, quoted in _Dawn to the West_[64]

### Industrial
disarmament[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Occupation_of_Japan&action=edit&section=19
"Edit section: Industrial disarmament")]

To further remove Japan as a potential future threat to the United States, the
[Far Eastern Commission](/wiki/Far_Eastern_Commission "Far Eastern
Commission") decided that Japan was to be partly de-industrialized. The
necessary dismantling of Japanese industry was foreseen to have been achieved
if Japanese standards of living had been reduced to those existing in Japan
the period 1930–1934.[65][66] In the end, the adopted program of de-
industrialization in Japan was implemented to a lesser degree than the similar
U.S. ["industrial disarmament" program in
Germany](/wiki/Industrial_plans_for_Germany "Industrial plans for
Germany").[65] In view of the cost to American taxpayers for emergency food
aid to Japan, in April 1948 the Johnston Committee Report recommended that the
economy of Japan should instead be reconstructed. The report included
suggestions for reductions in war reparations, and a relaxation of the
"economic deconcentration" policy. For the fiscal year of 1949 funds were
moved from the [GARIOA](/wiki/GARIOA "GARIOA") budget into an Economic
Rehabilitation in Occupied Areas (EROA) programme, to be used for the import
of materials needed for [economic
reconstruction](/wiki/Economic_reconstruction "Economic reconstruction").

###
Prostitution[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Occupation_of_Japan&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: Prostitution")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Yasuura_House.jpg/220px-
Yasuura_House.jpg)](/wiki/File:Yasuura_House.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Yasuura_House.jpg "Enlarge")

Allied servicemen visit the [Special Comfort Facility
Association](/wiki/Special_Comfort_Facility_Association "Special Comfort
Facility Association").

See also: [Recreation and Amusement
Association](/wiki/Recreation_and_Amusement_Association "Recreation and
Amusement Association")

With the acceptance of the Allied occupation authorities, the Japanese
organized a [brothel](/wiki/Brothel "Brothel") system for the benefit of the
more than 300,000 occupation troops. "The strategy was, through the special
work of experienced women, to create a breakwater to protect regular women and
girls."

In December 1945, a senior officer with the Public Health and Welfare Division
of the occupation's General Headquarters wrote regarding the typical
prostitute: "The girl is impressed into contracting by the desperate financial
straits of her parents and their urging, occasionally supplemented by her
willingness to make such a sacrifice to help her family", he wrote. "It is the
belief of our informants, however, that in urban districts the practice of
enslaving girls, while much less prevalent than in the past, still exists. The
worst victims ... were the women who, with no previous experience, answered
the ads calling for 'Women of the New Japan'."

MacArthur issued an order, SCAPIN 642 (SCAP Instruction), on January 21 ending
licensed brothels for being "in contravention of the ideals of democracy".
Although SCAPIN 642 ended the RAA's operations, it did not affect "voluntary
prostitution" by individuals. Ultimately, SCAP responded by making all
brothels and other facilities offering prostitution off-limits to Allied
personnel on March 25, 1946.[67] By November, the Japanese government had
introduced the new [akasen](/wiki/Akasen "Akasen") (赤線, _" red-line"_) system
in which prostitution was permissible only in certain designated
areas.[68][69]

###
Expulsions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Occupation_of_Japan&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: Expulsions")]

The surrender of Imperial Japan meant reversal of its previous
annexations—[Manchuria](/wiki/Manchuria "Manchuria")
([Manchukuo](/wiki/Manchukuo "Manchukuo") as a puppet regime under Japan) was
returned to [China](/wiki/Republic_of_China_\(1912%E2%80%9349\) "Republic of
China \(1912–49\)"), while [Korea](/wiki/Korea "Korea") regained its
independence and was [divided in two](/wiki/Division_of_Korea "Division of
Korea") by the United States and Soviet Union.

The Soviet Union claimed [South Sakhalin](/wiki/South_Sakhalin "South
Sakhalin") and the [Kuril Islands](/wiki/Kuril_Islands "Kuril Islands"), with
400,000 Japanese fleeing or expelled. Similar actions happened in Taiwan and
Manchuria after their return to China, while Korea saw the flight of over
800,000 Japanese settlers. In all, Japanese repatriation centers handled over
7 million expatriates returning to the Japanese main islands.[70]

### Soviet
activity[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Occupation_of_Japan&action=edit&section=22
"Edit section: Soviet activity")]

In a bid to occupy as much Japanese territory as possible, Soviet troops
continued offensive military operations after the Japanese surrender, causing
large scale civilian casualties.[71]

##
Politics[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Occupation_of_Japan&action=edit&section=23
"Edit section: Politics")]

Main article: [Reverse course](/wiki/Reverse_course "Reverse course")

Unlike [the case in Germany](/wiki/Allied-occupied_Germany "Allied-occupied
Germany"), Japan retained a native government throughout the occupation.
Although MacArthur's official staff history of the occupation referred to "the
Eighth Army [Military Government](/wiki/Military_occupation "Military
occupation") System", it explained that while "In Germany, with the collapse
of the Nazi regime, all government agencies disintegrated, or had to be
purged", the Japanese retained an "integrated, responsible government and it
continued to function almost intact":[72]

> In effect, there was no "military government" in Japan in the literal sense
> of the word. It was simply a SCAP superstructure over already existing
> government machinery, designed to observe and assist the Japanese along the
> new democratic channels of administration.

General [Horace Robertson](/wiki/Horace_Robertson "Horace Robertson") of
Australia, head of BCOF, wrote:[73]

> MacArthur at no time established in Japan what could be correctly described
> as Military government. He continued to use the Japanese government to
> control the country, but teams of military personnel, afterward replaced to
> quite a considerable extent by civilians, were placed throughout the
> [Japanese prefectures](/wiki/Japanese_prefectures "Japanese prefectures") as
> a check on the extent to which the prefectures were carrying out the
> directives issued by MacArthur’s headquarters or the orders from the central
> government.
>
>  
> The really important duty of the so called Military government teams was,
> however, the supervision of the issue throughout Japan of the large
> quantities of food stuffs and medical stores being poured into the country
> from American sources. The teams also contained so-called experts on health,
> education, sanitation, agriculture and the like, to help the Japanese in
> adopting more up to date methods sponsored by SCAP’s headquarters. The
> normal duties of a military government organisation, the most important of
> which are law and order and a legal system, were never needed in Japan since
> the Japanese government’s normal legal system still functioned with regard
> to all Japanese nationals ... The so-called military government in Japan was
> therefore neither military nor government.

The Japanese government's _de facto_ authority was strictly limited at first,
however, and senior figures in the government such as the Prime Minister
effectively served at the pleasure of the occupation authorities before the
first post-war elections were held. Political parties had begun to revive
almost immediately after the occupation began. Left-wing organizations, such
as the [Japan Socialist Party](/wiki/Japan_Socialist_Party "Japan Socialist
Party") and the [Japan Communist Party](/wiki/Japan_Communist_Party "Japan
Communist Party"), quickly reestablished themselves, as did various
conservative parties. The old [Seiyukai](/wiki/Seiyukai "Seiyukai") and
[Rikken Minseito](/wiki/Rikken_Minseito "Rikken Minseito") came back as,
respectively, the [Liberal Party](/wiki/Liberal_Party_\(Japan,_1945\) "Liberal
Party \(Japan, 1945\)") (Nihon Jiyuto) and the [Japan Progressive
Party](/wiki/Shimpot%C5%8D "Shimpotō") (Nihon Shimpoto). The first postwar
elections were held in 1946 (women were given the franchise for the first
time), and the Liberal Party's vice president, [Yoshida
Shigeru](/wiki/Yoshida_Shigeru "Yoshida Shigeru") (1878–1967), became [prime
minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Japan "Prime Minister of Japan"). For the
1947 elections, anti-Yoshida forces left the Liberal Party and joined forces
with the Progressive Party to establish the new [Japan Democratic
Party](/wiki/Democratic_Party_\(Japan,_1947\) "Democratic Party \(Japan,
1947\)") (Minshuto). This divisiveness in conservative ranks gave a plurality
to the Japan Socialist Party, which was allowed to form a
[cabinet](/wiki/Cabinet_of_Japan "Cabinet of Japan"), which lasted less than a
year. Thereafter, the socialist party steadily declined in its electoral
successes. After a short period of Democratic Party administration, Yoshida
returned in late 1948 and continued to serve as prime minister until 1954.

## Japanese American
contribution[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Occupation_of_Japan&action=edit&section=24
"Edit section: Japanese American contribution")]

See also: [Japanese American service in World War
II](/wiki/Japanese_American_service_in_World_War_II "Japanese American service
in World War II")

Japan accepted the terms of the Potsdam Declaration and surrendered on August
15, 1945. Over 5,000 [Japanese Americans](/wiki/Japanese_Americans "Japanese
Americans") served in the occupation of Japan.[74] Dozens of Japanese
Americans served as translators, interpreters, and investigators in the
[International Military Tribunal for the Far
East](/wiki/International_Military_Tribunal_for_the_Far_East "International
Military Tribunal for the Far East"). Thomas Sakamoto served as press escort
during the occupation of Japan. He escorted American correspondents to
Hiroshima, and the USS _Missouri_ in [Tokyo Bay](/wiki/Tokyo_Bay "Tokyo Bay").
Sakamoto was one of three Japanese Americans to be on board the USS _Missouri_
when the Japanese formally surrendered. Arthur S. Komori served as personal
interpreter for Brig. Gen. Elliot R. Thorpe. Kay Kitagawa served as personal
interpreter of Fleet Admiral [William Halsey Jr.](/wiki/William_Halsey_Jr.
"William Halsey Jr.").[75] Kan Tagami served as personal interpreter-aide for
General Douglas MacArthur.[76] Journalist Don Caswell was accompanied by a
Japanese American interpreter to [Fuchū Prison](/wiki/Fuch%C5%AB_Prison "Fuchū
Prison"), where the Japanese government imprisoned communists [Tokuda
Kyuichi](/wiki/Tokuda_Kyuichi "Tokuda Kyuichi"), [Yoshio
Shiga](/wiki/Yoshio_Shiga_\(Communist\) "Yoshio Shiga \(Communist\)"), and
Shiro Mitamura.[77]

Japanese Americans in the OSS parachuted down into Japanese POW prison camps
at Hankow, Mukden, Peiping and Hainan as interpreters on mercy missions to
liberate American and other Allied prisoners.[78] Arthur T. Morimitsu was the
only [Military Intelligence
Service](/wiki/Military_Intelligence_Service_\(United_States\) "Military
Intelligence Service \(United States\)") member in the detachment commanded by
Major Richard Irby and 1st Lt. Jeffrey Smith to observe the surrender ceremony
of 60,000 Japanese troops under Gen. Shimada.[79] Kan Tagami witnessed
Japanese forces surrender to the British in Malaya.[76]

## End of the
occupation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Occupation_of_Japan&action=edit&section=25
"Edit section: End of the occupation")]

In 1949, MacArthur made a sweeping change in the SCAP power structure that
greatly increased the power of Japan's native rulers, and the occupation began
to draw to a close. The [Treaty of San
Francisco](/wiki/Treaty_of_San_Francisco "Treaty of San Francisco"), which was
to end the occupation, was signed on September 8, 1951. It came into effect on
April 28, 1952, formally ending all occupation powers of the Allied forces and
restoring full sovereignty to Japan, except for the island chains of [Iwo
Jima](/wiki/Iwo_Jima "Iwo Jima") and [Okinawa](/wiki/Okinawa "Okinawa"), which
the United States continued to hold. Iwo Jima was returned to Japan in 1968,
and most of Okinawa was returned in 1972.

Following the American departure, Japan gained military protection from the
United States. However, the United States was soon pressuring Japan to rebuild
its military capabilities, and as a result, the [Japan Self-Defense
Forces](/wiki/Japan_Self-Defense_Forces "Japan Self-Defense Forces") were
formed as a _de facto_ military force with US assistance. However, following
the [Yoshida Doctrine](/wiki/Yoshida_Doctrine "Yoshida Doctrine"), Japan
continued to prioritize economic growth over defense spending, relying on
American protection to ensure it could focus mainly on economic recovery.
Through Guided Capitalism, Japan was able to optimally utilize its resources
to economically recover from the war, and revive industry.[80] Some 31,000 US
military personnel remain in Japan today at the invitation of the Japanese
government as the [United States Forces
Japan](/wiki/United_States_Forces_Japan "United States Forces Japan") under
the terms of the [Treaty of Mutual Cooperation and Security between the United
States and
Japan](/wiki/Treaty_of_Mutual_Cooperation_and_Security_between_the_United_States_and_Japan
"Treaty of Mutual Cooperation and Security between the United States and
Japan") (1960) and not as an occupying force. US bases in and around
[Tokyo](/wiki/Tokyo "Tokyo"), [Hiroshima](/wiki/Hiroshima "Hiroshima"),
[Nagasaki](/wiki/Nagasaki "Nagasaki"), [Aomori](/wiki/Aomori,_Aomori "Aomori,
Aomori"), [Sapporo](/wiki/Sapporo "Sapporo"), and [Ishikari](/wiki/Ishikari
"Ishikari") are currently active.

##
Criticism[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Occupation_of_Japan&action=edit&section=26
"Edit section: Criticism")]

On the day the occupation of Japan was over, the _[Asahi
Shimbun](/wiki/Asahi_Shimbun "Asahi Shimbun")_ published a very critical essay
on the occupation, claiming it turned the Japanese population "irresponsible,
obsequious and listless... unable to perceive issues in a forthright manner,
which led to distorted perspectives".[81] The purpose for delaying the return
of the Japanese southern islands, the [Bonin Islands](/wiki/Bonin_Islands
"Bonin Islands") including [Chichi Jima](/wiki/Chichi_Jima "Chichi Jima"),
[Okinawa](/wiki/Okinawa "Okinawa"), and the [Volcano
Islands](/wiki/Volcano_Islands "Volcano Islands") including [Iwo
Jima](/wiki/Iwo_Jima "Iwo Jima") to civil administration was the U.S.
military's requirement to covertly base U.S. atomic weapons or their
components on the islands where the presence or expansion of U.S. bases remain
a heated controversy to this day.

## Cultural
reaction[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Occupation_of_Japan&action=edit&section=27
"Edit section: Cultural reaction")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Sto1001.jpg/220px-
Sto1001.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sto1001.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Sto1001.jpg "Enlarge")

[Nihonbashi](/wiki/Nihonbashi "Nihonbashi"), Tokyo, in 1946

Hirohito’s surrender broadcast was a profound shock to Japanese citizens.
After years of being told about Japan’s military might and the inevitability
of victory, these beliefs were proven false in the space of a few minutes. But
for many people, these were only secondary concerns since they were also
facing starvation and homelessness.

Post-war Japan was chaotic. The [air raids on Japan's urban
centers](/wiki/Air_raids_on_Japan "Air raids on Japan") left millions
displaced and food shortages, created by bad harvests and the demands of the
war, worsened when the seizure of food from Korea, Taiwan, and China
ceased.[82] Repatriation of Japanese living in other parts of Asia and
hundreds of thousands of demobilized prisoners of war only aggravated the
problems in Japan as these people put more strain on already scarce resources.
Over 5.1 million Japanese returned to Japan in the fifteen months following
October 1, 1945, and another million returned in 1947.[83] Alcohol and drug
abuse became major problems. Deep exhaustion, declining morale and despair
were so widespread that it was termed the "kyodatsu condition" (虚脱状態,
_kyodatsujoutai_ , lit. "state of lethargy").[84] Inflation was rampant and
many people turned to the black market for even the most basic goods. These
black markets in turn were often places of turf wars between rival gangs, like
the [Shibuya incident](/wiki/Shibuya_incident "Shibuya incident") in 1946.
[Prostitution](/wiki/Prostitution "Prostitution") also increased considerably.

In the 1950s, [kasutori](/wiki/Kasutori "Kasutori") culture emerged. In
response to the scarcity of the previous years, this sub-culture, named after
the preferred drink of the artists and writers who imbibed it, emphasized
escapism, entertainment and decadence.[85]

The phrase "[shikata ga nai](/wiki/Shikata_ga_nai "Shikata ga nai")", or
"nothing can be done about it," was commonly used in both Japanese and
American press to encapsulate the Japanese public's resignation to the harsh
conditions endured while under occupation. However, not everyone reacted the
same way to the hardships of the postwar period. While some succumbed to the
difficulties, many more were resilient. As the country regained its footing,
they were able to bounce back as well.

Leftists looked upon the occupation forces as a "liberation army".[86]

## Japanese
women[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Occupation_of_Japan&action=edit&section=28
"Edit section: Japanese women")]

It has been argued that the granting of rights to women played an important
role in the radical shift Japan underwent from a war nation to a
[democratized](/wiki/Democratization "Democratization") and
[demilitarized](/wiki/Demilitarization "Demilitarization") country.[87] In the
first postwar general elections of 1946, over a third of the votes were cast
by women. This unexpectedly high female voter turnout led to the election of
39 female candidates, and the increasing presence of women in politics was
perceived by Americans as evidence of an improvement of Japanese women's
condition.[88]

American feminists saw Japanese women as victims of feudalistic and
chauvinistic traditions that had to be broken by the Occupation. American
women assumed a central role in the reforms that affected the lives of
Japanese women: they educated Japanese about Western ideals of democracy, and
it was an American woman who wrote the Japanese Equal Rights Amendment for the
new [constitution](/wiki/Constitution_of_Japan "Constitution of Japan").[89]
General [Douglas MacArthur](/wiki/Douglas_MacArthur "Douglas MacArthur") did
not mean for Japanese women to give up their central role in the home as wives
and mothers, but rather that they could now assume other roles simultaneously,
such as that of worker.[90][91]

In 1953, journalist Ichirō Narumigi commented that Japan had received
"liberation of sex" along with the "four presents" that it had been granted by
the occupation (respect for [human rights](/wiki/Human_rights "Human rights"),
[gender equality](/wiki/Gender_equality "Gender equality"), [freedom of
speech](/wiki/Freedom_of_speech "Freedom of speech"), and women’s
enfranchisement).[92] Indeed, the occupation also had a great impact on
relationships between man and woman in Japan. The "[modern
girl](/wiki/Modern_girl "Modern girl")" phenomenon of the 1920s and early
1930s had been characterized by greater sexual freedom, but despite this, sex
was usually not perceived as a source of pleasure (for women) in Japan.
Westerners, as a result, were thought to be [promiscuous](/wiki/Promiscuity
"Promiscuity") and sexually deviant.[93] The sexual liberation of European and
North American women during [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II")
was unthinkable in Japan, especially during wartime where rejection of Western
ways of life was encouraged.[94]

The Japanese public was thus astounded by the sight of some 45,000 so-called
"pan pan girls" ([prostitutes](/wiki/Prostitution "Prostitution"))
fraternizing with American soldiers during the occupation.[92] In 1946, the
200 wives of US officers landing in Japan to visit their husbands also had a
similar impact when many of these reunited couples were seen walking hand in
hand and kissing in public.[95] Both prostitution and marks of affection had
been hidden from the public until then, and this "democratization of
eroticism" was a source of surprise, curiosity, and even envy. The occupation
set new models for relationships between Japanese men and women: the western
practice of "[dating](/wiki/Dating "Dating")" spread, and activities such as
dancing, movies and coffee were not limited to "pan pan girls" and American
troops anymore, and became popular among young Japanese couples.[96]
